newsitem.title: UK: OPTIONS-Sell coffee calls to protect downside risk.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS-Sell coffee calls to protect downside risk.

text.p: Coffee players maintained a cautious stance on options this week while robusta futures set new lows as they searched for firmer ground.
But interest on rangebound cocoa has dried up, traders said.

January robusta options expired peacefully on Wednesday with no threat of mobilising the hefty open interest on $1,400 but some out-of-the-money puts were exercised, possibly to avoid further losses if these were sold into the futures market.
Selling crept in to March puts at $1,200 and $1,250 strikes and traders also cited some buying interest on calls at suspiciously distant strikes of $1,450, $1,500 and even $1,650.
"If you need cover, it's not a lot of money," commented one market maker.
Volatilities eased back to around 27 percent after last week's firmer 28 for March puts and calls, he said.

Scattered activity reflected the blurred direction in futures after the market took a pounding this week on increasing supply concerns while key Mexican coffee areas escaped frost damage from a cold airmass.

March coffee slipped through support at $1,231 and hit a new contract low of $1,225 a tonne on Friday. But some analysts said the market was likely to head lower towards $1,205 on continuation basis. In rangebound markets with a downside risk a good strategy singled out was to sell a strangle on March $1,400 call and $1,150 put. This would limit the losses if the market skidded to new low ground. Another possibility was to buy one $1,350 call and sell two $1,400 calls at a net credit of $2-3. This would protect the downside and generate some premium. Traders said the same deal could be applied to $1,300 and $1,350 for a more aggressive approach.
Cocoa options were wobbly with no appetite emerging for the few put sales that were on offer this week from players who thought the market may had bottomed out.
"There were some at-the-money put offers for March 900 and May 925, but we couldn't find any buyers," said one.
May 1,000 calls traded up to 18 stg with implied volatility at 20.5 percent.
March cocoa futures set a nine-month low of 899 stg where it encountered support. But technical analysts say 899 remains a threat while the market seems to have no stamina to rally.
In white sugar, the March contract dominated options activity, mainly on $320 calls, although some interest was also noted in out-of-the-money May puts.
Despite the bearish sentiment on the futures market, traders said underlying support was relatively solid although upside scope was probably limited.
"Everyone in the market is still a bit bearish," said one, adding that one strategy might be to sell a March strangle between $310 and $300.
March volatilities were quoted at between 12 and 13 percent, compared with a range of 10 and 11 previously.
